content.text:
<command-message>init is analyzing your codebase…</command-message>
                      <command-name>init</command-name>
                      <command-args></command-args>
                          <command-contents>{
  "type": "text",
  "text": "Please analyze this codebase and create a CLAUDE.md file, which will be given to future instances of Claude Code to operate in this repository.
            
What to add:
1. Commands that will be commonly used, such as how to build, lint, and run tests. Include the necessary commands to develop in this codebase, such as how to run a single test.
2. High-level code architecture and structure so that future instances can be productive more quickly. Focus on the "big picture" architecture that requires reading multiple files to understand

Usage notes:
- If there's already a CLAUDE.md, suggest improvements to it.
- When you make the initial CLAUDE.md, do not repeat yourself and do not include obvious instructions like "Provide helpful error messages to users", "Write unit tests for all new utilities", "Never include sensitive information (API keys, tokens) in code or commits" 
- Avoid listing every component or file structure that can be easily discovered
- Don't include generic development practices
- If there are Cursor rules (in .cursor/rules/ or .cursorrules) or Copilot rules (in .github/copilot-instructions.md), make sure to include the important parts.
- If there is a README.md, make sure to include the important parts. 
- Do not make up information such as "Common Development Tasks", "Tips for Development", "Support and Documentation" unless this is expressly included in other files that you read.
- Be sure to prefix the file with the following text:

```
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.
```"
}</command-contents>
I'll analyze this codebase and create a CLAUDE.md file to help future instances understand the architecture and common commands. Let me start by exploring the repository structure and key files.

     2	  "$schema": "packages/nx/schemas/nx-schema.json",
     3	  "namedInputs": {
     4	    "default": ["{projectRoot}/**/*", "sharedGlobals"],
     5	    "production": [
     6	      "default",
     7	      "!{projectRoot}/**/?(*.)+(spec|test).[jt]s?(x)?(.snap)",
     8	      "!{projectRoot}/tsconfig.spec.json",
     9	      "!{projectRoot}/jest.config.[jt]s",
    10	      "!{projectRoot}/.eslintrc.json",
    11	      "!{projectRoot}/.storybook/**/*",

    13	      "!{projectRoot}/tsconfig.storybook.json",
    14	      "!{projectRoot}/src/test-setup.[jt]s"
    15	    ],
    16	    "sharedGlobals": [
    17	      "{workspaceRoot}/babel.config.json",
    18	      "{workspaceRoot}/.nx/workflows/agents.yaml",
    19	      "{workspaceRoot}/.github/workflows/ci.yml"
    20	    ],
    21	    "native": [
    22	      "{projectRoot}/**/*.rs",
    23	      "{projectRoot}/**/Cargo.*",
    24	      {
    25	        "runtime": "node -p '`${process.platform}_${process.arch}`'"
    26	      },
    27	      {
    28	        "runtime": "rustc --version"
    29	      },
    30	      {
    31	        "externalDependencies": ["npm:@monodon/rust", "npm:@napi-rs/cli"]
    32	      }
    33	    ],

    37	      "{workspaceRoot}/.verdaccio/config.yml",
    38	      "{workspaceRoot}/scripts/local-registry/**/*",
    39	      "{workspaceRoot}/scripts/nx-release.ts",
    40	      {
    41	        "env": "SELECTED_CLI"
    42	      },
    43	      {
    44	        "env": "SELECTED_PM"
    45	      },
    46	      {

    48	      },
    49	      {
    50	        "env": "CI"
    51	      },

    57	  "release": {
    58	    "projects": ["packages/*", "packages/nx/native-packages/*"],
    59	    "releaseTagPattern": "{version}",
    60	    "changelog": {
    61	      "workspaceChangelog": {
    62	        "createRelease": "github",
    63	        "file": false
    64	      },
    65	      "git": {
    66	        "commit": false,
    67	        "stageChanges": false,
    68	        "tag": false
    69	      }
    70	    },
    71	    "version": {
    72	      "git": {
    73	        "commit": false,
    74	        "stageChanges": false,
    75	        "tag": false
    76	      },
    77	      "currentVersionResolver": "registry",
    78	      "preserveLocalDependencyProtocols": false,
    79	      "manifestRootsToUpdate": ["build/packages/{projectName}"],
    80	      "versionActionsOptions": {
    81	        "skipLockFileUpdate": true
    82	      }
    83	    }
    84	  },
    85	  "targetDefaults": {
    86	    "nx-release-publish": {
    87	      "options": {

    89	      }
    90	    },
    91	    "build": {
    92	      "dependsOn": ["build-base", "build-native"],
    93	      "inputs": ["production", "^production"],
    94	      "cache": true
    95	    },
    96	    "build-native": {
    97	      "inputs": ["native"],
    98	      "cache": true

   100	    "build-base": {

   102	      "inputs": ["production", "^production"],
   103	      "options": {

   106	        "main": "{projectRoot}/index.ts"
   107	      },
   108	      "outputs": ["{options.outputPath}"],
   109	      "cache": true
   110	    },
   111	    "test-native": {
   112	      "inputs": ["native"],

21 22 # Smart Repos · Fast Builds 23 24 Build system, optimized for monorepos, with AI-powered architectural awareness and advanced CI capabilities. 25 26 Create a new Nx workspace with 27 28 ```shell 29 npx create-nx-workspace 30 ``` 31 32 ...or run 33 34 ``` 35 npx nx init 36 ``` 37 38 to add Nx to your existing workspace to get faster task scheduling, caching and more. More [in the docs](https://nx.dev/getting-started/intro#try-nx-yourself). 39 40 ## Learn about CI with Nx Cloud 41 42 [Nx Cloud](https://nx.dev/nx-cloud) connects directly to your existing CI setup, helping you scale your monorepos on CI by leveraging [remote caching](https://nx.dev/ci/features/remote-cache?utm_source=nxrepo&utm_medium=readme&utm_campaign=nxrepo), [task distribution across multiple machines](https://nx.dev/ci/features/distribute-task-execution?utm_source=nxrepo&utm_medium=readme&utm_campaign=nxrepo), [automated e2e test splitting](https://nx.dev/ci/features/split-e2e-tasks?utm_source=nxrepo&utm_medium=readme&utm_campaign=nxrepo) and [automated task flakiness detection](https://nx.dev/ci/features/flaky-tasks?utm_source=nxrepo&utm_medium=readme&utm_campaign=nxrepo) 43 44 Connect your existing Nx workspace with 45 46 ``` 47 npx nx connect 48 ``` 49 50 Learn more in the [Nx CI docs »](https://nx.dev/ci/intro?utm_source=nxrepo&utm_medium=readme&utm_campaign=nxrepo) 51 52 ## Useful links 53 54 - [Our docs](https://nx.dev/docs) 55 - [Our blog](https://nx.dev/blog) 56 - [Our community discord, live stream,...](https://nx.dev/community) 57 - [Our YouTube channel](https://www.youtube.com/@NxDevtools) 58 - [Our Twitter/X](https://x.com/nxdevtools) 59 60

[![CircleCI](https://circleci.com/gh/nrwl/nx.svg?style=svg)](https://circleci.com/gh/nrwl/nx) [![License](https://img.shields.io/npm/l/nx.svg?style=flat-square)]() [![NPM Version](https://badge.fury.io/js/nx.svg)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/nx) [![Semantic Release](https://img.shields.io/badge/%20%20%F0%9F%93%A6%F0%9F%9A%80-semantic--release-e10079.svg?style=flat-square)]() [![Commitizen friendly](https://img.shields.io/badge/commitizen-friendly-brightgreen.svg)](http://commitizen.github.io/cz-cli/) [![Join the chat at https://gitter.im/nrwl-nx/community](https://badges.gitter.im/nrwl-nx/community.svg)](https://gitter.im/nrwl-nx/community?utm_source=badge&utm_medium=badge&utm_campaign=pr-badge&utm_content=badge) [![Join the Official Nx Discord Server](https://img.shields.io/discord/1143497901675401286?label=discord)](https://go.nx.dev/community)
# Smart Repos · Fast Builds Build system, optimized for monorepos, with AI-powered architectural awareness and advanced CI capabilities. Create a new Nx workspace with ```shell npx create-nx-workspace ``` ...or run ``` npx nx init ``` to add Nx to your existing workspace to get faster task scheduling, caching and more. More [in the docs](https://nx.dev/getting-started/intro#try-nx-yourself). ## Learn about CI with Nx Cloud [Nx Cloud](https://nx.dev/nx-cloud) connects directly to your existing CI setup, helping you scale your monorepos on CI by leveraging [remote caching](https://nx.dev/ci/features/remote-cache?utm_source=nxrepo&utm_medium=readme&utm_campaign=nxrepo), [task distribution across multiple machines](https://nx.dev/ci/features/distribute-task-execution?utm_source=nxrepo&utm_medium=readme&utm_campaign=nxrepo), [automated e2e test splitting](https://nx.dev/ci/features/split-e2e-tasks?utm_source=nxrepo&utm_medium=readme&utm_campaign=nxrepo) and [automated task flakiness detection](https://nx.dev/ci/features/flaky-tasks?utm_source=nxrepo&utm_medium=readme&utm_campaign=nxrepo) Connect your existing Nx workspace with ``` npx nx connect ``` Learn more in the [Nx CI docs »](https://nx.dev/ci/intro?utm_source=nxrepo&utm_medium=readme&utm_campaign=nxrepo) ## Useful links - [Our docs](https://nx.dev/docs) - [Our blog](https://nx.dev/blog) - [Our community discord, live stream,...](https://nx.dev/community) - [Our YouTube channel](https://www.youtube.com/@NxDevtools) - [Our Twitter/X](https://x.com/nxdevtools)

## Want to help? If you want to file a bug or submit a PR, read up on our [guidelines for contributing](https://github.com/nrwl/nx/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) and watch this video that will help you get started.

file.content:
---
description: 
globs: 
alwaysApply: true
---

// This file is automatically generated by Nx Console

You are in an nx workspace using Nx 21.2.0-beta.1 and pnpm as the package manager.

You have access to the Nx MCP server and the tools it provides. Use them. Follow these guidelines in order to best help the user:

# General Guidelines
- When answering questions, use the nx_workspace tool first to gain an understanding of the workspace architecture
- For questions around nx configuration, best practices or if you're unsure, use the nx_docs tool to get relevant, up-to-date docs!! Always use this instead of assuming things about nx configuration
- If the user needs help with an Nx configuration or project graph error, use the 'nx_workspace' tool to get any errors
- To help answer questions about the workspace structure or simply help with demonstrating how tasks depend on each other, use the 'nx_visualize_graph' tool

# Generation Guidelines
If the user wants to generate something, use the following flow: 

- learn about the nx workspace and any specifics the user needs by using the 'nx_workspace' tool and the 'nx_project_details' tool if applicable
- get the available generators using the 'nx_generators' tool
- decide which generator to use. If no generators seem relevant, check the 'nx_available_plugins' tool to see if the user could install a plugin to help them
- get generator details using the 'nx_generator_schema' tool
- you may use the 'nx_docs' tool to learn more about a specific generator or technology if you're unsure
- decide which options to provide in order to best complete the user's request. Don't make any assumptions and keep the options minimalistic
- open the generator UI using the 'nx_open_generate_ui' tool
- wait for the user to finish the generator
- read the generator log file using the 'nx_read_generator_log' tool
- use the information provided in the log file to answer the user's question or continue with what they were doing


# CI Error Guidelines
If the user wants help with fixing an error in their CI pipeline, use the following flow:
- Retrieve the list of current CI Pipeline Executions (CIPEs) using the 'nx_cloud_cipe_details' tool
- If there are any errors, use the 'nx_cloud_fix_cipe_failure' tool to retrieve the logs for a specific task
- Use the task logs to see what's wrong and help the user fix their problem. Use the appropriate tools if necessary
- Make sure that the problem is fixed by running the task that you passed into the 'nx_cloud_fix_cipe_failure' tool

input.content:
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Architecture Overview

This is the **Nx monorepo** - a build system and development toolkit for monorepos with AI-powered architectural awareness. The repository contains:

- **packages/**: Core Nx packages (nx, devkit, angular, react, next, etc.) - each package is a plugin that extends Nx functionality
- **nx-dev/**: Documentation website and related UI components 
- **docs/**: Documentation content (markdown files, blog posts, guides)
- **graph/**: Project graph visualization components
- **e2e/**: End-to-end tests for all packages
- **tools/**: Workspace-specific tooling and plugins

The workspace uses a **hybrid TypeScript/Rust architecture**:
- TypeScript for core logic, plugins, and tooling
- Rust for performance-critical operations (hashing, file operations) in `packages/nx/src/native/`

## Essential Commands

### Development
```bash
# Build all packages
pnpm build

# Run tests for all packages  
pnpm test

# Run specific package tests
nx test <package-name>

# Run e2e tests
pnpm e2e

# Build with native Rust components
pnpm build:wasm

# Format check
nx format:check --all

# Lint check
pnpm check-format
```

### Testing
```bash
# Test specific package
nx test @nx/angular

# Test with specific pattern
nx test --testNamePattern="<pattern>"

# E2E tests for specific functionality
nx e2e e2e-angular

# Run local registry for testing
pnpm local-registry
```

### Development Tools
```bash
# Check commit messages
pnpm check-commit

# Check imports
pnpm check-imports  

# Check lock files
pnpm check-lock-files

# Documentation generation
pnpm documentation

# Release workflow
pnpm nx-release
```

## Package System

Nx uses a **plugin-based architecture** where each package in `packages/` extends core functionality:

- **@nx/nx**: Core Nx functionality and CLI
- **@nx/devkit**: API for building Nx plugins
- **@nx/angular**: Angular support
- **@nx/react**: React support  
- **@nx/next**: Next.js support
- **@nx/jest**: Jest testing integration
- **@nx/cypress**: Cypress e2e testing
- **@nx/webpack**: Webpack build support

Each package follows the structure:
- `src/`: Source code with executors, generators, and utilities
- `executors.json` & `generators.json`: Plugin configuration
- Individual TypeScript path mappings in `tsconfig.base.json`

## Nx Configuration

- **nx.json**: Workspace configuration with target defaults, plugins, and caching rules
- **project.json**: Individual project configurations  
- **tsconfig.base.json**: TypeScript path mappings for all packages
- Uses **pnpm** as package manager
- Rust toolchain for native components (see `rust-toolchain.toml`)

## Testing Strategy

- **Unit tests**: Jest for all packages
- **E2E tests**: Comprehensive test suite in `e2e/` covering integration scenarios
- **Local registry**: Tests use local npm registry for isolated testing
- Native components tested with Rust test framework

## Development Workflow

1. Most development happens in `packages/` - each package is independently testable
2. Use Nx commands to build/test specific packages: `nx <target> <project>`
3. E2E tests validate cross-package functionality
4. Local registry (`pnpm local-registry`) enables testing package installations
5. Native Rust components require `pnpm build:wasm` for compilation

The workspace is optimized for **incremental development** - Nx's caching and dependency graph ensure only affected projects are rebuilt/tested.

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Repository Purpose

This is the **Nx source repository** - the codebase for Nx, a build system and development toolkit optimized for monorepos. Nx provides:

- **Smart task execution** with caching and parallelization
- **Code generation** via generators and schematics  
- **Project graph analysis** to understand dependencies
- **Plugin ecosystem** for frameworks like Angular, React, Next.js, etc.
- **CI optimization** through affected project detection
- **Nx Cloud integration** for distributed builds and caching

The repository contains both the core Nx tooling and all official plugins, making it a comprehensive monorepo management solution.

# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Architecture Overview

This is the **Nx monorepo** - a build system and development toolkit for monorepos with AI-powered architectural awareness. The repository contains:

- **packages/**: Core Nx packages (nx, devkit, angular, react, next, etc.) - each package is a plugin that extends Nx functionality
- **nx-dev/**: Documentation website and related UI components 
- **docs/**: Documentation content (markdown files, blog posts, guides)
- **graph/**: Project graph visualization components
- **e2e/**: End-to-end tests for all packages
- **tools/**: Workspace-specific tooling and plugins

The workspace uses a **hybrid TypeScript/Rust architecture**:
- TypeScript for core logic, plugins, and tooling
- Rust for performance-critical operations (hashing, file operations) in `packages/nx/src/native/`

## Essential Commands

### Development
```bash
# Build all packages
pnpm build

# Run tests for all packages  
pnpm test

# Run specific package tests
nx test <package-name>

# Run e2e tests
pnpm e2e

# Build with native Rust components
pnpm build:wasm

# Format check
nx format:check --all

# Lint check
pnpm check-format
```

### Testing
```bash
# Test specific package
nx test @nx/angular

# Test with specific pattern
nx test --testNamePattern="<pattern>"

# E2E tests for specific functionality
nx e2e e2e-angular

# Run local registry for testing
pnpm local-registry
```

### Development Tools
```bash
# Check commit messages
pnpm check-commit

# Check imports
pnpm check-imports  

# Check lock files
pnpm check-lock-files

# Documentation generation
pnpm documentation

# Release workflow
pnpm nx-release
```

## Package System

Nx uses a **plugin-based architecture** where each package in `packages/` extends core functionality:

- **@nx/nx**: Core Nx functionality and CLI
- **@nx/devkit**: API for building Nx plugins
- **@nx/angular**: Angular support
- **@nx/react**: React support  
- **@nx/next**: Next.js support
- **@nx/jest**: Jest testing integration
- **@nx/cypress**: Cypress e2e testing
- **@nx/webpack**: Webpack build support

Each package follows the structure:
- `src/`: Source code with executors, generators, and utilities
- `executors.json` & `generators.json`: Plugin configuration
- Individual TypeScript path mappings in `tsconfig.base.json`

## Nx Configuration

- **nx.json**: Workspace configuration with target defaults, plugins, and caching rules
- **project.json**: Individual project configurations  
- **tsconfig.base.json**: TypeScript path mappings for all packages
- Uses **pnpm** as package manager
- Rust toolchain for native components (see `rust-toolchain.toml`)

## Testing Strategy

- **Unit tests**: Jest for all packages
- **E2E tests**: Comprehensive test suite in `e2e/` covering integration scenarios
- **Local registry**: Tests use local npm registry for isolated testing
- Native components tested with Rust test framework

## Development Workflow

1. Most development happens in `packages/` - each package is independently testable
2. Use Nx commands to build/test specific packages: `nx <target> <project>`
3. E2E tests validate cross-package functionality
4. Local registry (`pnpm local-registry`) enables testing package installations
5. Native Rust components require `pnpm build:wasm` for compilation

The workspace is optimized for **incremental development** - Nx's caching and dependency graph ensure only affected projects are rebuilt/tested.

## Essential Commands

### Pre-commit Validation
```bash
# Full validation suite - run before committing
pnpm check-format           # Check code formatting
pnpm check-imports          # Validate import statements  
pnpm check-lock-files       # Ensure lock files are valid
pnpm check-commit           # Validate commit message format

# Quick format check (faster alternative)
pnpm check-format:quick
```

### Testing Changes
```bash
# Test only affected projects (recommended for development)
nx affected:test

# Test specific package you're modifying
nx test <package-name>

# Run all tests (use for major changes)
pnpm test

# E2E validation for specific functionality
nx e2e e2e-<framework>      # e.g., e2e-angular, e2e-react

# Full e2e suite (thorough but slow)
pnpm e2e
```

### Build Validation  
```bash
# Build only affected projects
nx affected:build

# Build all packages (full validation)
pnpm build

# Build with native Rust components (if touching native code)
pnpm build:wasm
```

### Integration Testing
```bash
# Set up local registry for package testing
pnpm local-registry

# Test package installations in isolation
# (run in separate terminal after local-registry is running)
```

### Development Tools
```bash
# Check commit messages
pnpm check-commit

# Check imports
pnpm check-imports  

# Check lock files
pnpm check-lock-files

# Documentation generation
pnpm documentation

# Release workflow
pnpm nx-release
```

## Package System

Nx uses a **plugin-based architecture** where each package in `packages/` extends core functionality:

- **@nx/nx**: Core Nx functionality and CLI
- **@nx/devkit**: API for building Nx plugins
- **@nx/angular**: Angular support
- **@nx/react**: React support  
- **@nx/next**: Next.js support
- **@nx/jest**: Jest testing integration
- **@nx/cypress**: Cypress e2e testing
- **@nx/webpack**: Webpack build support

Each package follows the structure:
- `src/`: Source code with executors, generators, and utilities
- `executors.json` & `generators.json`: Plugin configuration
- Individual TypeScript path mappings in `tsconfig.base.json`

## Nx Configuration

- **nx.json**: Workspace configuration with target defaults, plugins, and caching rules
- **project.json**: Individual project configurations  
- **tsconfig.base.json**: TypeScript path mappings for all packages
- Uses **pnpm** as package manager
- Rust toolchain for native components (see `rust-toolchain.toml`)

## Testing Strategy

- **Unit tests**: Jest for all packages
- **E2E tests**: Comprehensive test suite in `e2e/` covering integration scenarios
- **Local registry**: Tests use local npm registry for isolated testing
- Native components tested with Rust test framework

## Development Workflow

1. Most development happens in `packages/` - each package is independently testable
2. Use Nx commands to build/test specific packages: `nx <target> <project>`
3. E2E tests validate cross-package functionality
4. Local registry (`pnpm local-registry`) enables testing package installations
5. Native Rust components require `pnpm build:wasm` for compilation

The workspace is optimized for **incremental development** - Nx's caching and dependency graph ensure only affected projects are rebuilt/tested.

## Essential Commands

### Pre-commit Validation
```bash
# Full validation suite - run before committing
pnpm check-format           # Check code formatting
pnpm check-imports          # Validate import statements  
pnpm check-lock-files       # Ensure lock files are valid
pnpm check-commit           # Validate commit message format

# Quick format check (faster alternative)
pnpm check-format:quick
```

### Testing Changes
```bash
# Test only affected projects (recommended for development)
nx affected:test

# Test specific package you're modifying
nx test <package-name>

# Run all tests (use for major changes)
pnpm test

# E2E validation for specific functionality
nx e2e e2e-<framework>      # e.g., e2e-angular, e2e-react

# Full e2e suite (thorough but slow)
pnpm e2e
```

### Build Validation  
```bash
# Build only affected projects
nx affected:build

# Build all packages (full validation)
pnpm build

# Build with native Rust components (if touching native code)
pnpm build:wasm
```

### Integration Testing
```bash
# Set up local registry for package testing
pnpm local-registry

# Test package installations in isolation

content.text:
I've rewritten the Essential Commands section to focus on validating code changes safely. The new structure emphasizes:

**Pre-commit Validation**: Commands to run before committing to catch issues early
- Format, import, lock file, and commit message validation
- Quick vs thorough options

**Testing Changes**: Progressive testing approach 
- `nx affected:test` for efficient testing of only changed code
- Specific package testing for targeted changes
- Full test suite for major changes
- E2E testing options

**Build Validation**: Incremental and comprehensive build verification
- `nx affected:build` for efficient builds
- Full builds for comprehensive validation
- Native/Rust build validation when needed

**Integration Testing**: Local registry setup for testing package installations

This approach emphasizes Nx's "affected" capabilities for efficient validation and provides a clear progression from quick checks to comprehensive validation based on the scope of changes.
